A few nights before I left the hostel another British guy joined our dorm. He was honestly one of the most inconsiderate people I have met in my life. When sleeping in a dorm with a bunch of other people, what kind of person would turn on the light and start talking loudly when some other people are obviously sleeping? This guy would. What kind of person would ask someone from Serbia: "Hey, didn't you guy murder a bunch of people in Kosovo back in the day?". Him again. And who would have very loud sex in a dorm room, with yours truly was trying to get some sleep in the bottom bunk? Yep, this guy.

Needless to say, I was quite happy to be on the road again to Vienna, where I'd stay with some people I've met on the road.

title: Vienna
content:
It was nice to cycle back into Austria and to be able to understand everything and everyone again. It was a bit less nice that my luggage set-up was slowly falling apart. I rammed one of my "indestructible" Ortlieb panniers into a fence, which caused the pannier-hangers to snap. To cycle with all my gear I had to carry everything I had strapped on my rack on my back and rig my pannier with cut-up inner-tubes on my rack. This unstable set-up obviously failed a few times at inconvenient moments while cycling through Vienna.

I spent three lovely nights with people I have met on the road in Vienna. The first two days I spent with Jadh, a Brazilian girl studying in Vienna whom I met in Bratislava. We went to a fancy museum, complained about her ex moving to Vienna (the nerve of the man!), walked around town for a day (Jadh forgot the key to her apartment, so there was quite some walking involved) and went out to a Christmas market. I even got a private room because one of her roommates was gone for a couple of days, which I very much enjoyed after a long time in a hostel.

For the last night I moved to Sophie's place. Sophie is an Austrian girl who invited me to show me around town when I was in Budapest. She gave me a very elaborate tour of the city, including getting kaiserschmarrn at St. Stephens cathedral. We went to another Christmas market that night with some of her friends. Eventually we ended up playing Mario Cart at one of her friend's homes and getting late night snacks at around 2 am.

Reconnecting with people I met before on the road and the general Christmas-y atmosphere in Vienna felt like a very appropriate closure of my trip. I left with spring-like weather, a lot of rain and moderate temperatures, I experienced summer in southern Europe, saw the leaves turn in Croatia and Hungary, so the start of the Christmas-season made me feel like I have had an entire year's worth of seasons on my trip. Again, thanks for the lovely experiences, Jadh and Sophie!

Next day I had to get the train to Passau, from where I would get my connection to Duisburg. I took a bit longer then I wanted to get my (broken) pack set up again, so I had to rush a bit to catch the train. I knew I was cycling with good speed because I even caught up with a delivery guy on an e-bike. Cycling for a few months apparently made me a good bit faster then I used to be.

title: Night cycling
content:
When booking my train tickets I had some trouble finding a connection that would take me and my bike home. There actually is a direct sleeper from Vienna to my home town, but sadly this train does not have spaces for bicycles yet. If you took away the sleeper trains, you end up with the problem that trains just stop going at a certain time. To get from west Germany to the Netherlands you would usually take local trains, and those do not go in the middle of the night. So, the only connection that would take us both for a reasonable price ended up stopping in Duisburg, somewhere in the Ruhr area, at 2 am.

It would be possible to book a hotel close to the railway station and head to Arnhem the next day, but that would be expensive and above all, very lame. So, I decided that I would just cycle through the night. The trip would be a bit under 100km, which should be a doable distance. I was a bit concerned that it would be rainy and cold. I prepared in the train to layer all my warm clothes on top of each other. Luckily the conditions were actually fine: dry, no wind and about 8 degrees. 

While this all sounds very hard-core, the ride itself was quite easy. The road were near-perfect and flat, which was a lot better then most of the roads I have had the past months. It was a bit challenging sometimes to see in front of me since not all roads were well-lit, but my headlight provided enough illumination to figure out where to ride. You can't really take a break at a coffee shop somewhere, but I managed to find a gas station to sell me a bottle of water to keep me going. 

It was actually quite nice to enjoy a different version of the world in this trip. I got to see a few parties going on while starting out on my ride, I saw lots of empty roads in the middle and I had breakfast at the border while everyone else was getting their Sunday-morning bread. Only at the very end I noticed that I was getting a bit tired. Luckily I was almost home by then...

title: Back home
content:
After four months and thousands of kilometers of cycling I finally returned to the place where I set off from. After dealing with the dogs going crazy because of my return I stumbled to bed and slept for a few hours. Being "home" still felt a bit weird, I have gotten so used to moving around that it did not really feel like my own space yet. Somehow the only place that felt really mine was the inside of my tent.

The next days I was catching up on all the missed comfyness by spending a lot of time watching TV and cuddling the dogs. I also started feeling the consequences of cycling through the night, so that matched pretty well with my new passive lifestyle. By now (at the end of November) I am settled in to a rhythm of sports, working on my own software and planning my next trips.

I am not really sure how to describe what I was looking for, besides a cool experience, when I left. It could have been freedom, the freedom to decide every day how to get the most out of it. Maybe it was also curious if I can, in a very literal sense, survive by myself in the real world, without all the comforts of a social network, a home and a job. It could also have been escaping from the "rail road" of life, where once you get a job and a house, you just move up the career and real-estate ladders, where each move upwards makes it harder to leave that track. 

Whatever it was that I was looking for, I returned with the feeling that I have found "it". While sleeping somewhere else every night is not something I would enjoy for many years to come, I do want to have a good part of the adventure and dynamism of my traveling lifestyle permanently. I also just do not want to return to a 9-to-5 office-lifestyle anymore. Since I am privileged with my skill-set and (both financial and non-financial) assets, I want to focus on completing meaningful projects, with part-time salaried work just as a way to get a stable income.

For now my plans after winter are to give the digital-nomad lifestyle a go. I would like to work remotely for a few days per week and spend the rest on developing my own software, while switching locations every few weeks or months. Perhaps I will get myself a folding bicycle to take with me, so I can more easily take trains and buses. But for now I will entertain myself with planning, programming and enjoying the comforts of a stationary life.
